results.title: Smoking and lung cancer
results.creator_credit: Robert Anderson Associates and Robert Anderson
results.brief_description: A strong indictment of medical men of smoking as a general health risk, this film follows an actual patient through his diagnosis, discussions with the surgeon, and the actual operation for the removal of a lung and the exposure of the cancer in the excised lung. Filmed at the Royal Edward Chest Hospital in Montreal.

results.title: Smoking and kids
results.creator_credit: Sandler Institutional Films, Morley Skolnek and Bryon Meyers
results.brief_description: Many children are caught up in peer pressures that induce them to drink, eat, inhale or inject substances that may harm them. This film provides an opportunity to bring some of the children’s problems into the open, and to think about alleviating them.

results.title: Smoking and health: a report to youth
results.creator_credit: Design Center, Bailey Film Productions and Jeff Whatley
results.brief_description: If you smoke, chances are that you will get lung cancer. Is smoking worth the chance? This is the only question asked in the film and the answer must come from the viewer after they have seen how the human body is affected by smoking. The evidence against smoking is over-whelming but the decision rests with the individual.

results.title: Smokey Joe's revenge
results.brief_description: When nasty old Mr. Williams replaces his ols steam engine with a new model, three local children repair and restore the old engine (Smokey Joe). They win first prize at the steam engine fair, but Mr. Williams takes the trophy, claiming Smokey Joe is his engine. But Smokey Joe has plans of his own.

results.title: Smokey and the hot wire gang
results.creator_credit: Westernro, Ace Pix and Anthony Cardoza
results.brief_description: Car chases abound in this action-packed story of a youth gang who strike fear into the citizens of a small town with their crazy and dangerous speed racing and the efforts of a group of truckers to locate a beautiful, hot-rodding car thief. Cast includes George Barris, James Keach and Carla Ziegfield.

results.title: Smokey and the bandit
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Rastar Films, Mort Engelberg and Hal Needham
results.brief_description: When maverick truck driver “Bandit” (Burt Reynolds) is approached by a father and son team at a Truck Rodeo, it sparks the beginning of a wild ride from Georgia to Texas. The challenge is for Bandit to drive from one state to the other, collect a truckload of Coors beer, and return with the precious load within 28 hours. The challenge has been laid before but never completed. The reward is $80,000, the danger lies in the fact that his actions qualify as bootlegging (taking beer across state lines without a permit is illegal). Bandit enlists the help of his buddy, “The Snowman” (Jerry Reed), while Bandit rides shotgun in a 1976 Black Trans Am - Bandit One. Before long a damsel in distress joins the small crew when Bandit picks up hitchhiking runaway bride Carrie (Sally Field). Carrie was supposed to be marrying Junior, and her future father-in-law, Sheriff Buford T Justice (Jackie Gleason), aka “The Bandit”, is soon in pursuit of his son’s intended. Whilst it didn’t receive much critical success, this slice of 70s nostalgia is laden with silly and sexist one liners, impressive car chase sequences, a fondness for the culture of CB radios and an anti-authoritarian stance. Having said that, it also took $126+ million at the box office.

results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: 1:1 Films, South Australian Film Corporation, Penny Chapman and Gillian Armstrong
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Smokers' lungs
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Don Hopkins and Joe Licastro
results.brief_description: No one would inflict external injury to himself—because the consequence is immediately seen and felt. The lungs, however, being out of sight, can be subjected to years of abuse before a smoker takes warning. In this film, Dr. D.W. Thompson of the Toronto General Hospital demonstrates, through a series of color slides of lungs and lung tissue, how the persistent, prolonged irritation of cigarette smoke can bring about drastic, even fatal, changes in the lungs—convincing evidence that smoking can and does cause cancer and other lung disease. A film for the lay audience as well as for use by medical personnel.

results.title: Smoke signal
results.brief_description: Stressing the importance of forest products to Tasmania, this film deals with the causes of forest firest and methods of control. Shows how each township has its own volunteer Rural Fire Organisation, supplemented by the fire-fighting resources of the Forestry Department - cooperation to keep Tasmania green. The main causes of fire are smoldering cigarette butts, camp fires left unattended, and the deliberate burning of dry grass.
